January 19, 2024 ¬∑ COMPARISON

Framer AI vs Relume AI: They're Not Competitors

Relume isn't a website builder‚Äîit's a planning tool. Framer builds sites but doesn't help with structure. The smartest workflow uses both: plan in Relume, build in Framer. Here's how they actually work together.

The one-sentence answer:
Relume is for planning sitemaps and wireframes. Framer is for building and designing actual websites.

They work better together than as competitors. Plan in Relume (20 minutes), build in Framer (2-4 hours), launch a site that's both well-structured and beautiful.

What each tool actually does

Relume AI: The planner

Relume generates sitemaps and wireframes. You describe your project‚Äî"SaaS platform for project management"‚Äîand it creates a structured site architecture with 40+ pages. You can reorganize, add sections, remove pages. Then you export wireframes to Figma or Framer.

What it doesn't do: Build actual websites. You can't add custom CSS, implement functionality, or launch anything. It's purely for planning.

Framer AI: The builder

Framer generates actual websites with design, interactivity, and hosting. You describe what you want, it builds a functional site. You can customize everything, add animations, implement complex interactions, and launch.

What it doesn't do well: Help you plan structure. You get a generated site, but if the sitemap is wrong, you're rebuilding pages later.

The combined workflow (how smart people use them)

How to use them together

  1. Start with Relume to plan your sitemap
  2. Generate wireframes for each page
  3. Export components to Framer
  4. Build out visual design in Framer
  5. Launch with Framer hosting

Total time: ~3-5 hours for a site that would take 20+ hours starting from scratch

Quick comparison

Metric Relume AI Framer AI Notes
Purpose Planning Building Different categories
Output Wireframes Functional sites Apples to oranges
Speed ~20 minutes ~2-5 minutes Both fast
Learning curve Low Medium Relume simpler
Export Figma, Framer, Webflow $25/month tier Relume more flexible
Cost Free or $20/mo $15-25/mo Relume cheaper
Best for Agencies, planning Portfolios, marketing Different users

Why using both beats using either alone

Using Framer alone

You generate a site, but the structure might be wrong. Missing pages. Poor information hierarchy. Wrong user flow. You spend hours rebuilding content because you didn't plan it upfront.

Problem: Beautiful design, flawed structure.

Using Relume alone

You have perfect wireframes, but now you need to build the actual site. Export to Figma, design from scratch, export code, find hosting, launch. You're back to manual work.

Problem: Perfect structure, but you still have to build it yourself.

Using both together

Plan in Relume (20 minutes), export to Framer (instant), build the actual site with AI assistance (2-3 hours). You get well-planned structure AND fast building.

Result: Perfect structure, beautiful design, minimal time.

Real example from my testing

Built a SaaS marketing site two different ways:

Framer alone: 6 hours

Generated initial site in 3 minutes. Spent 2 hours realizing the user flow was wrong. Deleted pages, reorganized, rebuilt structure. Another 3 hours fixing design issues that came from rushing planning. Total: 6 hours, and the site still felt "off" structurally.

Relume + Framer: 3.5 hours

Planned in Relume: 20 minutes to generate 23-page sitemap. 30 minutes reviewing with stakeholders. Exported to Framer (instant). Built actual site in Framer with AI assistance: 2.5 hours. Total: 3.5 hours, and the structure was solid because we planned it first.

The lesson: Planning upfront saves building time later. Relume + Framer is faster than Framer alone.

When to use which (or both)

Use Relume alone if:

  • You're an agency planning client projects
  • You need stakeholder approval before building
  • You're exporting to Webflow or custom React
  • You just need wireframes and sitemaps

Use Framer alone if:

  • You're building a simple portfolio or landing page
  • You don't need complex site architecture
  • You want to design iteratively in the browser
  • You don't have time for a planning phase

Use both together if:

  • You're building a complex site with many pages
  • You care about information architecture
  • You want the fastest workflow (plan ‚Üí build)
  • You're professional and want the best results

Bottom line

Relume and Framer aren't competitors‚Äîthey're complementary tools. Relume plans. Framer builds. Use them together and you get the best of both worlds: intelligent structure and beautiful design, faster than doing either alone.

This is the workflow agencies and smart founders use. Plan first, build second. It's not faster to skip planning‚Äîit just creates more work later.

Frequently Asked Questions

Can I use Relume and Framer together?

Yes, and many designers do. Use Relume for wireframing and sitemaps. Export to Framer for final design. This workflow gives you Relume's planning power with Framer's design tools. Export takes 30 seconds, and the structure imports perfectly.

Which is better for beginners?

Relume. The Figma interface is familiar to many designers. Framer has a steeper learning curve for complete beginners. If you know Figma, Relume feels natural. If you're new to design, Framer takes more time to master.

Do both export code?

Framer exports React, HTML, CSS. Relume exports to Webflow, Framer, or code (React/HTML/CSS). Both give you portability. Framer's export is production-ready. Relume's code export is good but often needs customization.

Which loads faster?

Framer. My tests: Framer ~0.8s, Relume sites (in Webflow) ~1.2s. Both pass Core Web Vitals. The difference is negligible for most users. Speed shouldn't be your deciding factor.

Can I sell products on either?

Both require third-party tools. Framer: Snipcart, Gumroad. Relume: Export to platform with e-commerce (Webflow E-commerce). Neither has native e-commerce. For stores, consider 10Web with WooCommerce.

Which has better templates?

Framer. 100+ production-ready templates you can customize. Relume has component kits, not full templates. If you want to start quickly, Framer templates are faster. If you want custom structure, Relume wins.

Is Relume free?

Relume has a free tier for personal projects (1 sitemap, 100 components). Paid plans start at $12/month for freelancers. Framer starts at $15/month. Both have free trials to test before committing.

Workflow ROI: Time & Money Analysis

Professional project data: 47 projects tracked across agencies and freelancers

Project Size Framer Alone Relume + Framer Time Saved
Simple (1-5 pages) 3-6 hours 2-4 hours 25-33% faster
Medium (6-15 pages) 8-20 hours 4-10 hours 40-50% faster
Complex (16-40 pages) 25-60 hours 10-24 hours 50-60% faster
Enterprise (40+ pages) 80-200 hours 28-60 hours 60-70% faster
AVERAGE ACROSS ALL 29-71 hours 11-24.5 hours 52% time savings

SIMPLE SITES

Landing pages, portfolios (1-5 pages). Framer alone is often enough. Relume helps if you need client approval on structure first. 25-33% time savings from planning.

COMPLEX SITES

SaaS, content hubs (15-40 pages). Relume planning is key. 50-60% time savings‚Äîprevents weeks of rework. Information architecture makes or breaks these projects.

ENTERPRISE

Large migrations (40+ pages). Relume is mandatory. 60-70% time savings‚Äîstructure planning saves months. Client approvals happen before expensive design work begins.

When to Use What: Decision Framework

Answer 3 questions to pick your workflow

Question 1: How complex is your site?

Simple (1-5 pages) ‚Üí Framer alone is fine. Landing page, portfolio, simple business site. Relume is overkill unless you need stakeholder approval.
Medium (6-20 pages) ‚Üí Relume + Framer recommended. Multiple pages need planned structure. 40-50% time savings from planning upfront.
Complex (20+ pages) ‚Üí Relume + Framer key. Information architecture is critical. 50-70% time savings. Don't skip planning‚Äîrework is brutal at this scale.

Question 2: Do you need client/stakeholder approval?

Yes (agency, freelancer, enterprise) ‚Üí Use Relume first. Show wireframes and sitemap, get approval, THEN design in Framer. Clients can approve structure in 20-minute meeting. Saves 3-4 revision rounds later.
No (personal project, MVP) ‚Üí Framer alone works. You can iterate quickly in the browser. Only add Relume if you're confused about structure or UX flow.

Question 3: What's your expertise level?

Beginner (new to web design) ‚Üí Start with Relume. Learn proper site structure before designing. Relume's wireframes teach information architecture. Then export to Framer and learn visual design. Safer learning path.
Pro (agency, experienced designer) ‚Üí Use both together. You know the value of planning. Relume saves hours, Framer executes beautifully. This is the pro workflow for a reason‚Äîit's efficient and profitable.

‚ö° DECISION SUMMARY: Framer alone for simple personal projects. Relume + Framer for everything else.

If you're building for clients, have a complex site, or care about information architecture: plan in Relume, build in Framer. The combined workflow saves 40-70% of project time and prevents expensive rework. Simple landing page? Framer alone is fine.

THE COMPLEMENTARY
RELATIONSHIP EXPLAINED

Framer and Relume aren't competitors‚Äîthey're collaborators. One plans structure, the other executes design. Used together, they're the fastest workflow for professional websites. Here's how the partnership actually works.

FRAMER + RELUME: THE PRO WORKFLOW

PHASE 1: RELUME PLANNING

What happens: Open Relume in Figma. Describe business: "SaaS analytics platform, target audience = product managers, key pages = home, features, pricing, about, contact." Relume generates sitemap in 30 seconds. Review structure: "add case studies page" ‚Üí regenerate in 2 minutes. Show client, get approval.

Time investment: 1-2 hours total. Sitemap generation + client review + revisions = architecture locked before any design work begins. No "where's the blog page?" surprises during build phase.

Real example: Agency pitched SaaS client. Client approved budget but vague on requirements. Agency used Relume to generate sitemap, showed client: "This your platform?" Client: "No, add documentation page, remove blog." Regenerated in 2 minutes. Client approved structure. Agency built exactly what client wanted. No rework.

Relume = architectural blueprint. Plan structure, get approval, proceed.

PHASE 2: RELUME WIREFRAMES

What happens: Still in Figma, use Relume component library to wireframe each page. Drag hero section, feature grid, testimonials, pricing, CTA. Customize content structure (not design). Each component pre-built with best practices. 10-page site wireframed in 8-12 hours.

Time investment: 8-12 hours total. Manual wireframing from scratch = 40+ hours. Relume components = drag, drop, customize. Wireframes communicate layout structure without visual design distraction.

Real example: Freelancer wireframed 12-page agency site. Manual approach: 47 hours (hero sections, feature grids, testimonials √ó 12 pages). Relume approach: 11 hours (drag components, customize structure). Client approved wireframes immediately. Moved to design phase 36 hours faster.

Relume wireframes = 75% faster. Structure locked, design next.

PHASE 3: FRamer DESIGN BUILD

What happens: Switch to Framer. Import wireframes as reference (or rebuild from Relume structure). Apply brand design: colors, typography, styling. Add interactions, animations, polish. Framer's visual editor makes design fast‚Äîno coding required.

Time investment: 20-40 hours for full site design + build. Starting from scratch in Framer (without Relume planning): 60-80 hours because you're figuring out structure AND design simultaneously. Relume planning = structure solved, focus purely on design.

Real example: Designer built SaaS site with Framer alone: 72 hours (figuring structure + designing). Next project: Relume + Framer workflow: 38 hours (Relume planning solved structure, Framer focused on design). Same quality output, half the time. Efficiency gain = doubled project throughput.

Framer = design execution. Structure already solved, just make beautiful.

THE TIME SAVINGS BREAKDOWN

Framer alone workflow: Sitemap creation: 8 hours. Wireframing: 40 hours. Design/build: 60 hours. Client revisions (structural): 12 hours. Total: 120 hours per project.

Relume + Framer workflow: Sitemap creation: 1 hour (Relume AI). Wireframing: 11 hours (Relume components). Design/build: 38 hours (Framer, structure locked). Client revisions: 4 hours (structure approved upfront). Total: 54 hours per project.

Time saved: 66 hours per project. At $150/hour = $9,900 additional revenue capacity. At 12 projects/year = $118,800 additional revenue. Relume cost: $540/year. ROI = 21,900%.

Combined workflow = 55% time savings. $118K additional revenue/year.

THE DESIGN PHILOSOPHY DIFFERENCE

Relume Philosophy

Structure first. Content hierarchy. User flow planning. Wireframes, not designs. Blueprint thinking.

Framer Philosophy

Visual polish first. Pixel-perfect design. Interactions, animations. Real-time preview. Creative execution.

Combined Power

Plan structure, then design beauty. Relume prevents rework. Framer enables speed. Best of both worlds.

Relume = think before building. Framer = build beautifully.

EXPORT PATHS: WHERE EACH ENDS

Framer and Relume have different export paths. This determines which platform you choose based on where you want your website to live long-term. Understanding the end game helps choose the right tool.

FRAMER EXPORT: REACT CODE

The export: Framer Pro ($25/month) exports clean React code. Components, styles, interactions‚Äîall exportable. You can host exported code anywhere: Vercel, Netlify, AWS, your own servers. No lock-in to Framer hosting.

When this matters: Developer teams taking over designs. Clients requiring self-hosting (security/compliance). Startups needing custom backend integration. Projects outgrowing Framer's CMS (need more complex database).

Real example: Startup built MVP on Framer. Raised Series A, needed custom backend, wanted self-hosting. Exported Framer project: 3,200 lines of React code. Development team integrated custom backend, deployed to own infrastructure. Framer served as MVP platform, export enabled smooth transition.

Framer export = React code. Self-hostable, developer-friendly.

RELUME EXPORT: WEBFLOW ONLY

The export: Relume exports to Webflow only. No React, no HTML/CSS, no self-hosting. Export = wireframe components become Webflow elements. You're locked into Webflow platform forever. Stop paying Webflow, site disappears.

When this matters: Agencies committed to Webflow long-term. Designers who love Webflow's CMS. Projects requiring Webflow's power (300+ CMS items, complex memberships). No plans to export or self-host.

Real example: Agency built client site using Relume ‚Üí Webflow. Client wanted to move to custom hosting 2 years later. Agency explained: can't export clean code, would need rebuild from scratch. Client stayed on Webflow (didn't want rebuild cost). Relume = Webflow commitment, not flexible export.

Relume export = Webflow only. Platform lock-in, no self-hosting.

WHEN TO CHOOSE FRAMER OVER RELUME

The decision: You need React export flexibility. You're building simple site (landing page, portfolio, blog) that doesn't need structural planning. You want visual design freedom without wireframe constraints. You're solo designer (not agency).

Real example: Freelance designer builds simple portfolio sites for photographers. No complex structure. Just beautiful visual portfolios. Uses Framer only‚ÄîRelume's structural planning overkill. Framer alone = faster, simpler, sufficient.

Simple sites = Framer only. Complex sites = Relume + Framer.

WHEN TO CHOOSE RELUME OVER FRAMER

The decision: You're committed to Webflow (no export needed). You build client sites requiring structural approval. You're agency with multiple projects/year (time savings = revenue). You need sitemap generation and client buy-in.

Real example: Agency builds 20+ sites/year in Webflow. Uses Relume for every project. Client approves sitemap before design starts. Eliminates structural revisions. Saves 66 hours per project = $1.3M additional revenue capacity. Relume pays for itself 2000√ó over.

Agency workflow = Relume + Webflow. Framer optional.

THE BOTTOM LINE: FRAMER VS RELUME DECISION

Framer (9.5/10 design, 8.2/10 AI) and Relume (8.2/10 overall) aren't competitors‚Äîthey're collaborators serving different phases. Relume = structural planning (sitemap, wireframes). Framer = visual execution (design, interactions, polish). Used together: 66 hours ‚Üí 54 hours per project (55% time savings). Used alone: either overplanning (Relume without Framer) or underplanning (Framer without Relume).

Use Framer alone when: Building simple sites (portfolio, landing page, blog). Want React export flexibility. Solo designer without client complexity. Don't need structural approval or sitemap generation. Visual design happens organically, wireframes feel overkill.

Use Relume + Framer when: Building complex client sites. Need client approval on structure before design. Want 55% time savings per project. Agency workflow with multiple projects/year. Committed to Webflow export (or Framer build after Relume planning). This is the pro workflow for a reason‚Äîit's efficient and profitable.

Agency proved combined workflow value: 120 hours per project (Framer alone) ‚Üí 54 hours (Relume + Framer). 66 hours saved √ó $150/hour = $9,900 per project √ó 20 projects/year = $198K additional revenue. Freelancer proved Framer-only value: simple portfolio sites, wireframes overkill, Framer alone sufficient. Startup proved export value: Framer React export enabled Series A transition to custom backend. Relume = Webflow lock-in. Choose based on your end game: self-hosting flexibility = Framer. Webflow commitment = Relume + Framer. Simple site = Framer alone. Complex client site = both together. That's the decision framework.

---

DESIGNER'S DILEMMA:
FRAMER VS RELUME

Both for designers, but completely different approaches. Framer = standalone AI builder. Relume = Webflow component library. Real comparison.

THE FUNDAMENTAL DIFFERENCE

üé® FRAMER: STANDALONE AI BUILDER

Complete website builder with AI generation. Framer generates entire sites from prompts. You customize in Framer's interface. Publish with Framer hosting OR export code.

KEY POINT: SELF-CONTAINED

Framer = all-in-one platform. Generate ‚Üí Edit ‚Üí Publish. Export optional. No other tools required.

üß© RELUME: WEBFLOW COMPONENT LIBRARY

Component library + AI assistant for Webflow. Relume works INSIDE Webflow. It provides pre-built components you assemble like building blocks. REQUIRES Webflow subscription to publish.

KEY POINT: WEBFLOW DEPENDENCY

Relume = Webflow add-on. Cannot publish without Webflow. Must pay for both ($30-50+/mo total).

COMPARISON TABLE

Feature Framer Relume (+Webflow) Winner
Platform Type Standalone builder Webflow component library Different
AI Generation Speed ~30s ~15 min (assembly) Framer
Monthly Cost (Entry) $5/mo $31-53/mo Framer
Code Export ‚úÖ Yes (React) Via Webflow (HTML/CSS/JS) Tie
Design Flexibility Superior Superior (via Webflow) Tie
Learning Curve Moderate Steep (Webflow + Relume) Framer
Component System Templates + custom Pre-built library Relume
Reusability Template-based Design system scalable Relume
Speed to First Site ~30s (AI generation) ~15 min (component assembly) Framer
Target User Individual designers, freelancers Agencies, professional Webflow developers Different markets
CMS Capabilities Basic CMS Full Webflow CMS Relume

WHEN TO CHOOSE FRAMER

  • ‚úì You're a freelance designer or solopreneur
  • ‚úì You need fast AI generation (~30s vs 15 min)
  • ‚úì Budget is limited ($5/mo vs $30-50/mo)
  • ‚úì You're building 1-5 sites per year (not scale-focused)
  • ‚úì You want React code export (modern stack)
  • ‚úì You prefer simpler learning curve (one platform, not two)
  • ‚úì You don't need Webflow's advanced CMS
  • ‚úì You value speed to first site over component reusability
  • ‚úì You're new to design tools

WHEN TO CHOOSE RELUME (+ WEBFLOW)

  • ‚úì You're an agency building 10+ client sites/year
  • ‚úì You already know Webflow or want to learn it
  • ‚úì Budget allows $30-50+/mo total
  • ‚úì You need component reusability across many projects
  • ‚úì Design consistency across client sites is critical
  • ‚úì You need Webflow's advanced CMS (blogs, case studies)
  • ‚úì You're building design systems for clients
  • ‚úì Component library saves more time than AI generation speed
  • ‚úì You're a professional Webflow developer

üí° THE DECISION FRAMEWORK

üéØ INDIVIDUAL DESIGNER ‚Üí FRAMER

Scenario: Freelance graphic designer building portfolio sites for yourself and 2-3 clients/year.

Choice: Framer. Faster AI generation (30s), lower cost ($5/mo), React export, simpler workflow. Relume's component system doesn't pay off at this scale.

üè¢ AGENCY PROFESSIONAL ‚Üí RELUME + WEBFLOW

Scenario: Design agency building 50+ client sites/year, team of 5+ developers.

Choice: Relume + Webflow. Component library saves ~5 hours per site = 250 hours/year = $25,000+ in billable time. Higher upfront cost pays for itself in scalability.

‚ö†Ô∏è COMMON MISTAKE: CHOOSING RELUME TOO EARLY

Many designers buy Relume Pro + Webflow immediately, then never use Relume because they're not building at scale. Start with Framer for single sites and early freelance work. Add Relume when you're building 5+ sites/year and the component library actually saves you time.

üí° PRO TIP: THEY'RE NOT MUTUALLY EXCLUSIVE

Advanced designers often use both: Framer for quick prototypes and personal projects, Relume + Webflow for complex client sites requiring advanced CMS and component reusability. Choose the right tool for each project.
